pros: Good Staffing, Flexibility, Good Benefits

pros: -working 3 days a week 12 hour shifts -provides online education modules/resources that are helpful -decent amount of paid time off and wellness time off although this has to be accrued based on hours worked and isn’t a fixed number of days
cons: -poor working conditions…supplies are scarce and broken vital machines on unit -understaffed and higher ups do not care about having safe staff to patient ratios -charge nurses/clinical shift supervisors will not support/help you when you need it and are incompetent -leaders are quick to scrutinize things you can do better without acknowledging positives thus creating nurse burnout -poor leadership all around…will ask what things need to be improved on the unit but won’t actually do anything to make positive changes -not enough teamwork from peers

pros: It’s a job with so called benefits.
cons: Too many politics. If a RN is already max in salary, he or she will still get a raise due to their market research adjustment. However if you are not a RN regardless if you invested your body, time and soul to the institution for 30 years with good performance reviews, you are still out of luck. Oh btw the department has a high turnover every year. It’s all bs because if they did a real market research, that person should have gotten a raise. It’s a very low morale hospital and willing to replace you with grads regardless if the pt care suffers and everything else also. Serves them right to lose people in rapid pace.

pros:
Amazing coworkers 
Great doctors 
Average pay
Clean hospital 
Updated
cons: No room for advancement. Very sad that all these employees who worked there tail off during covid and got sick themselves. Did not get a dime. From the 50 million dollars you got from the government you could not even give your employees in the hospital and medical groups who are exposing themselves to this deadly virus putting there lives on the line. Not even 1000 dollar bonus for our outstanding and courageous work. But instead you took away all our r4r bonus’s and every other bonus we could have gotten Not even a employee was announced as the legend out of the quarterly champions for the year was and given the award for it. Instead they were told the company is holding off. It is such a disgrace that all hard working employees are trying to help with the virus and exposing themselves to it.can’t get compensated from the 50 million dollars given to you buy the government. We’re the ones getting furloughed and struggling. It really puts in perspective of how the employees are valued. Very very sad

pros: Patients are at the center of care and employees are hired similarly, it feels like working with extended family, management is held to standards of safety culture so staff are empowered to seek their help, annual raises. Staff level is treated very well, very fairly.
cons: Very little growth potential past manager, partly due to size of organization being self-limiting. Objective ways of choosing candidates for leadership roles are not consistent and sometimes follow "who is next in line" for a promotion.

pros: Great community hospital, and excellent nursing care.

pros: Good place to start your career in the medical field.
cons: More support needed from mgmt.

pros: Everyone has been working together during this. As frontline workers we have been there for one another.
cons: Valley Hospital sure makes you feel undervalued and unappreciated as a healthcare worker! ALL employees from neighboring hospitals got a big bonus from their employees for working through this pandemic. What did Valley Hospital give their employees..? A sweater...as a Christmas gift and as a “thank you for all your hard work during this pandemic”. Unbelievable!

pros: Medical benefits at a reasonable cost
cons:
-Low pay
-Bullying by unit supervisors (permanent charge RNs) is rampant and long-standing in some areas (i.e. CCU). It is the expectation and norm to "deal with it."  If you end up working there,  you will either have to deal with the toxic behavior, or you may end up  targeted and terminated without just cause.  
-No value on continuing education (conferences, seminars, certification prep, etc are paid out of pocket/must go to educational events on your own time outside of work hours/no differential for certifications)
-Education in in-house clinical units are lacking
-Preach 'just culture,' but practices culture of blame 
-Shared governance is non-existent, with leadership heavily running all committees. Input by bedside RNs are basically ignored, and management &  administration agendas are pushed
-Poor nurse/physician relationships
-Terrible vacation policies: The weeks around Christmas and New Year are permanently blocked. PTO and vacation requests are not allowed-AT ALL. Expect to work these weeks every year. Vacation requests are by seniority-Even if you request a year in advance for something  (i.e. wedding), a more senior nurse can (and will) take your spot last minute.  Plan to stay for a long time if you want a vacation during prime times. You also have to work an extra weekend day if you call in sick on a weekend (everyone is hired every other weekend).

pros: Good benefits and woek environment.

pros: none i can think of at the moment
cons: management does not value hard work

pros: The Hospital is amazing.  The patient care top notch.  The benefits are fabulous.  The employees truly care.
cons: The employees are not appropriately rewarded for the contributions they make.  Compensation is below standard.  Bonuses for the staff level employee are based on patient satisfaction scores that are impossible to reach when the hospital is as busy as it is.  Work life balance posture is anti quated.  Some of the leaders in business support, Human Resources etc are complacent, have been there too long and turn a blind eye towards issues.  A very Stepford Wives like environment.  Talented high performers are quickly turned off and leave.  There is no opportunity for advancement.  Those who have been in positions of leadership for decades refuse to mentor for fear they will be replaced.

review_title: Transparent, Organized, and proud of their accolades
pros: Employees stay here... there is a low turnover.  The environment is very nice to work in.  People follow the protocols, policies, and procedures and everything is very well organized.  The compensation is competitive, but so are your colleagues.  The people that work here are good at what they do and you can learn a great deal from being here.
cons: Sometimes too many policies and procedures are followed to a fault.  It is the "stepford wives" of hospitals in that regard.

pros: Some coworkers are very helpful and most charge nurses are willing to help. The pay and differentials are extremely competitive with nearby hospitals. When talking to nurses who work in neighboring hospitals, it seems as though the work environment and general patient outcomes are much better at Valley. Doctors are usually very nice, professional, and informative, and do not mind being called for further questions or orders.
cons: Certain charge nurses, nurses, and PCA's are most of the time unwilling to leave the nurses station. This requires other nurses to help their patients in addition to their own assignments, and answer additional call bells, adding to workload. This can make shifts much more difficult and unsafe for patients.

review_title: Thankful to work where I'm valued
pros: Working with people who are committed to doing the right thing and always willing to help each other to get the work done;   I know I'm contributing to our goals because managers take time to express appreciation; financial stability as a not for profit that reinvests in programs, services and employees so I don't worry about my future prospects as long as I continue to perform well
cons: can't think of anything major -- any drawbacks are common to any healthcare system like fewer holidays than in corporate/for-profit settings

pros: Great people, interesting work, would NOT recommend
cons: Management has no clue how to keep staff or to at least try to keep them happy

review_title: The people were nice to work with, IS management is a little behind with the latest technology.
pros: Friendly work environment for the most part
cons: Poor leadership skills.  IS has a huge turn over rate therefore they loose very talented people.

pros: Valley has a distinct family feeling, the culture and commitment to quality is nothing like any other place I have worked.  The senior leadership is committed to safe and compassionate care.  The staff at the bedside, have a passion for healthcare like non other.  This is not only the hospital i work for but he hospital I trust my family and myself to!
cons: My only con is the distance from my home, however I drive past several other hospitals to be part of this family!

pros: Tuition reimbursement, benefits decent
cons: Disconnect between staff and management ( dept directors).  A lot of smoke and mirrors , we talk a good one but don’t walk the talk. It’s all about persona, not committed to fixing poor nursing care environment. Only listen if you’re telling them how great they are. Minute you bring important issues forward your career is done.  Some managers who advocate get the same treatment. Others don’t care.  Sad.

pros: I have a job that allows me to put food on my table
cons: EXTREMELY hard to move up. There is a lot of favoritism. Management has their favorite and if you are not one of them, they make life so hard for you. Don’t have a BSN? Forget about the opportunity to further your career in this company. I have a bachelors and currently working on a masters degree and I keep getting denied when applying to other departments. It is sad to say this but it is hard to move up if you are a minority. Hopefully this changes someday.

pros: I have a job that pays me
cons: EXTREMELY hard to move up. There is a lot of favoritism. Management has their favorite and if you are not one of them, they make life so hard for you. Don’t have a BSN? It is sad to say this but it is hard to move up if you are a minority. Hopefully this changes someday.

pros: The nursing staff is great. They work together, help without having to be asked, strive for top-notch service to their patients, patients' families and co-workers. Nursing is always working to improve everyone's experience and outcome.
cons: Can overrun your life with the constant committee meetings. Hard to advance unless you take on an improvement project or get deeply involved in any of the many ongoing initiatives. Have moved to an all BSN hiring policy.

pros: The people I work with are some of the nicest coworkers I’ve had and are always willing to help. Everyone here is so experienced that it’s also a great learning experience for someone just getting into healthcare and they’ve made sure to work with me during my journey.
cons: Opportunities for advancement don’t come often as I’m guessing people don’t want to give up their jobs!

pros: Flexible hours; often work with team of great people, fair wage, convenient location via bus or car, opportunity to advance
cons: Parking can be difficult at times, depending on your work schedule and/or building location(s); Business Associate must earn respect from coworker RNs & DRs as BA position sometimes viewed as of secondary importance.
